se.sensiblethings.disseminationslayer.communication.security.certificate

Class CertificateOperations

  • java.lang.Object
    • se.sensiblethings.disseminationslayer.communication.security.certificate.CertificateOperations

  • public class CertificateOperations
extends java.lang.Object
    CertificateOperations.java This class specify the all operations concerning about certificate. The SIGNATURE_ALGORITHM is predefined as "SHA256WithRSAEncryption". And many functions are under the BouncyCastle libraries. Though the poor documentations of BouncyCastle, the libraries supported by JDK are more difficult and some are old-fashioned.
    Author:
    Hao

      The signature algorithm

      Sign the Certificate request and generate the certificate chain including the Bootstrap Root certificate and applicants' certificate signed by Bootstrap.
      static org.bouncycastle.jce.PKCS10CertificationRequest generateCertificateSigningRequest(java.lang.String subjectName, java.security.KeyPair keyPair)
      Generate the PKCS10 Certificate Signing Request The extra extension part is not fully used here, as this protocol do not need them.
      static java.security.cert.X509Certificate generateSelfSignedcertificate(java.lang.String subjectName, java.security.KeyPair keyPair, long lifeTime)
      Generate the Self Signed X509V1 Certificate (Root Certificate) There is one solution to generate the X509 certificate without using the Bouncy Castle Detail can be found from below (Actually it's similar to doSelfCert from the keytool souce code):
      void standOutInPemEncoded(java.security.cert.X509Certificate cert)
      Write the Certificate out in PEM format For certificates, the available formats are PEM, DER and PKCS12 In general, the PEM formats are mostly used in the Unix world, PCKS12 in the Microsoft world and DER in the Java world.

    • Method Detail

      • generateSelfSignedcertificate

        public static java.security.cert.X509Certificate generateSelfSignedcertificate(java.lang.String subjectName,
                                                               java.security.KeyPair keyPair,
                                                               long lifeTime)
        Generate the Self Signed X509V1 Certificate (Root Certificate) There is one solution to generate the X509 certificate without using the Bouncy Castle Detail can be found from below (Actually it's similar to doSelfCert from the keytool souce code):

        Parameters:
        subjectName - The specification of X.500 distinguished name
        keyPair - The RSA key pair
        lifeTime - The lifetime of this certificate
        Returns:
        X509 version 1 certificate(a root certificate)
        See Also:
        1, creating-an-x509-certificate-in-java-without-bouncycastle

        , 2,odds_and_ends_creating_a_new_x_509_certificate

        While sun.security.* package is required which has some contradiction with support/ stable principle So here decide to use Bouncy Castle to implement this

      • generateCertificateSigningRequest

        public static org.bouncycastle.jce.PKCS10CertificationRequest generateCertificateSigningRequest(java.lang.String subjectName,
                                                                                java.security.KeyPair keyPair)
        Generate the PKCS10 Certificate Signing Request The extra extension part is not fully used here, as this protocol do not need them.
        Parameters:
        subjectName - The subject name of in this request
        keyPair - The RSA key pair
        Returns:
        PKCS10 certificate request

      • buildChain

        public static java.security.cert.X509Certificate[] buildChain(org.bouncycastle.jce.PKCS10CertificationRequest request,
                                              java.security.cert.X509Certificate rootCert,
                                              java.security.KeyPair rootPair,
                                              long lifeTime)
                                                       throws java.security.InvalidKeyException,
                                                              java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException,
                                                              java.security.NoSuchProviderException,
                                                              java.security.SignatureException,
                                                              java.security.cert.CertificateParsingException
        Sign the Certificate request and generate the certificate chain including the Bootstrap Root certificate and applicants' certificate signed by Bootstrap.
        Parameters:
        request - PKCS10 Certificate request from the applicant
        rootCert - Bootstrap's root certificate
        rootPair - Bootstrap's RSA key pair
        lifeTime - The life time of the signed certificate
        Returns:
        Certificate chain including the Bootstrap Root certificate and X509V3 certificate signed by Bootstrap
        Throws:
        java.security.InvalidKeyException
        java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException
        java.security.NoSuchProviderException
        java.security.SignatureException
        java.security.cert.CertificateParsingException

      • standOutInPemEncoded

        public void standOutInPemEncoded(java.security.cert.X509Certificate cert)
        Write the Certificate out in PEM format For certificates, the available formats are PEM, DER and PKCS12 In general, the PEM formats are mostly used in the Unix world, PCKS12 in the Microsoft world and DER in the Java world.
        Parameters:
        cert - The certificate that will be write out
